p: Viruses transmitted by arthropods (arboviruses) and other human microbial pathogens have been emerging (not reemerging) for centuries. Arthropod vectors and their feeding preferences (anthropophilic or ornithophilic) play an important role in the geographical expansion of these diseases ( Gould et al., 2003, Gould and Solomon, 2008). Recent evidence based on the sequencing of DNA and nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of Aedes aegypti supports the evidence that shows that mosquito populations in the New World are derived directly from African populations. A. aegypti originated in Africa and then colonized the Americas, Oceania and the Asian tropics through trade during the 17thâ€“19th centuries ( Powell and Tabachnick, 2013, Brown et al., 2011, Brown et al., 2014, Bennett et al., 2016, Crawford et al., 2017). This redistribution of A. aegypti coincided with the appearance of yellow fever and dengue fever in the Americas and dengue fever in Asia ( Gould et al., 2003, Tabachnick, 1991, Urdaneta-Marquez and Failloux, 2011).
